SubTopics: Identify and describe examples of common technological changes past to present in the community (e.g., energy production, transportation, communications, agriculture, packaging materials) that have either positive or negative impacts on society or the environment.
Content: Which process has increased the availability of fresh food to many people all over the United States?

A.Choice: boiling and storing food in glass jars

Key.Rationale: Boiling and storing food in glass jars preserves it for later use.

B.Choice: packing meat in salt to remove water

Key.Rationale: Packing meat in salt preserves the meat for later use.
Refrigerated transport of food improves people's access to fresh food.

D.Choice: using stoves powered by natural gas to cook food

Key.Rationale: Using stoves allows people to heat and prepare food.

SubTopics: Explain what happens to a living organism when its food supply, access to water, shelter, or space is changed (e.g., it might die, migrate, change behavior, eat something else).
Content: Use the food web below to answer the question.
problems/PA21G4S/media/2a.jpg
Cold temperatures reduced the snake population in this food web. How will the hawks most likely respond to this change in their environment?

Key.Rationale: Hawks do not hibernate.

B.Choice: The hawks will eat more deer mice.

Key.Rationale: With fewer snakes available to eat, the hawks will eat more deer mice.

C.Choice: The hawks will feed on wheat plants.

Key.Rationale: Hawks are carnivores; they do not eat plants.

D.Choice: The hawks will use sunlight to produce energy.

Key.Rationale: Producers, not hawks, use sunlight to produce energy.

SubTopics: Provide examples, predict, or describe how everyday human activities (e.g., solid waste production, food production and consumption, transportation, water consumption, energy production and use) may change the environment.
Content: Use the drawing below to answer the question.
problems/PA21G4S/media/3a.jpg
Breakfast cereals are usually packaged in one of two ways. Which statement best compares these two types of packaging?

A.Choice: Type X produces less waste than type Y.

Key.Rationale: Without the cardboard box, type X produces less waste than type Y.

B.Choice: Type X costs more to produce than type Y.

Key.Rationale: Type X uses fewer resources for packaging, which reduces costs.

C.Choice: Type X helps keep cereal fresh longer than type Y.

Key.Rationale: Type Y has more packaging, which means type Y may keep cereal fresh longer than type X.

D.Choice: Type X protects cereal better during shipping than type Y.

Key.Rationale: Type Y has more packaging, which means type Y may protect cereal better than type X.

SubTopics: Observe a natural phenomenon (e.g., weather changes, length of daylight/night, movement of shadows, animal migrations, growth of plants), record observations, and then make a prediction based on those observations.
Content: Use the drawings below to answer the question.
problems/PA21G4S/media/4a.jpg
When is the next time that the shadow will look most similar to the shadow at 7:00 a.m.?

Key.Rationale: The shadow at 5:00 a.m. will be shorter than the shadow at 7:00 a.m.
The shadow at 7:00 a.m. the next morning will be most similar to the shadow at the same time on the previous day.
Evening shadows appear on the opposite side of the stick as in the morning.
The shadow at 7:00 p.m. will be on the opposite side of the stick as the shadow at 7:00 a.m.

SubTopics: State a conclusion that is consistent with the information/data.
Content: Use the table below to answer the question.
problems/PA21G4S/media/5a.jpg
Bird watchers at Hawk Mountain Sanctuary in Pennsylvania recorded the number of hawks observed during four days in August. Which conclusion can best be made from the data?

A.Choice: The greatest number of hawks was observed on day 4.

Key.Rationale: Twenty-one hawks were observed on day 4, which is more than on any other day.

B.Choice: Broad-winged hawks fly faster than other types of hawks.

Key.Rationale: These data do not compare flight speed of different types of hawks.

C.Choice: More red-tailed hawks were observed than sharp-shinned hawks.

Key.Rationale: Observers counted 8 sharp-shinned hawks and 7 red-tailed hawks.

D.Choice: Migrating hawks prefer Hawk Mountain Sanctuary over other bird sanctuaries.

Key.Rationale: These data do not compare hawk observations from other bird sanctuaries.

SubTopics: Categorize the parts of an ecosystem as either living or nonliving and describe their roles in the system.
Content: Use the chart below to answer the question.
problems/PA21G4S/media/6a.jpg
Which part of the pond ecosystem is correctly described in the chart?

Key.Rationale: Water is a nonliving part of a pond ecosystem.
Algae are a living part of a pond ecosystem.
A snail is a living part of a pond ecosystem.
Fish are living consumers in a pond ecosystem.

SubTopics: Use models to make observations to explain how systems work (e.g., water cycle, Sun-Earth-Moon system).
Content: Use the drawing below to answer the question.
problems/PA21G4S/media/7a.jpg
A student builds a model to show some of the steps in the water cycle. Which steps in the water cycle is the student most likely modeling?

Key.Rationale: This model shows water sprinkling out of a can (precipitation) and water flowing across the sand surface (runoff).
This model shows runoff but does not show condensation.
This model shows precipitation but does not show evaporation.
This model shows neither condensation nor evaporation.

SubTopics: Predict future conditions/events based on observable patterns (e.g., day/night, seasons, sunrise/sunset, lunar phases).
Content: Use the graph below to answer the question.
problems/PA21G4S/media/8a.jpg
About how much will the diameter of the tree's trunk most likely increase between year 200 and year 230?

Key.Rationale: The pattern suggests the tree will grow 1 cm in diameter every 3 years.
The pattern suggests the tree will grow 10 cm in diameter over 30 years.
It takes the tree approximately 75 years to increase its diameter by 25 cm.
It takes the tree approximately 150 years to increase its diameter by 50 cm.

SubTopics: Identify physical characteristics (e.g., height, hair color, eye color, attached earlobes, ability to roll tongue) that appear in both parents and could be passed on to offspring.
Content: Which physical characteristic can be passed on to offspring?

Key.Rationale: A long beard is a characteristic acquired during a person's lifetime; it is not genetic and cannot be passed from parents to offspring.
Arm strength is acquired during a person's lifetime; it is not genetic and cannot be passed from parents to offspring.
A pierced ear is a characteristic acquired during a person's lifetime; it is not genetic and cannot be passed from parents to offspring.
Hair color is a genetic trait that is passed from parents to offspring.

SubTopics: Describe interactions between living and nonliving components (e.g. plants – water, soil, sunlight, carbon dioxide, temperature; animals – food, water, shelter, oxygen, temperature) of a local ecosystem.
Content: Erie National Wildlife Refuge has many creeks, ponds, and marshes. It attracts over 200 types of birds. Which birds depend most on the water in the refuge?

Key.Rationale: Birds that eat fish depend on water habitats to support the fish.
Hibernation reduces an organism's need for food or water.
Birds that eat snakes depend on their eyesight and talons for survival.
Birds that build nests depend on nesting materials and protective cover.

SubTopics: Describe the human dependence on the food and fiber systems from production to consumption (e.g., food, clothing, shelter, products).
Content: Which sequence shows the most likely steps humans use to produce lumber from trees for construction purposes?

Key.Rationale: Planting is the first step required to produce lumber from trees.
During lumber production, growing occurs before harvesting and processing occurs before shipping.
Planting is the first step required to produce lumber from trees.
This sequence shows how humans produce lumber from trees.

SubTopics: Recognize or illustrate simple direct current series and parallel circuits composed of batteries, light bulbs (or other common loads), wire, and on/off switches.
Content: Use the diagram below to answer the question.
problems/PA21G4S/media/12a.jpg
Which change is necessary for this circuit to work?

Key.Rationale: A working circuit requires a power source to provide electric current.
Adding a second light bulb simply increases the load in the circuit.

C.Choice: Move the switch farther away from the light bulb.

Key.Rationale: Moving the switch farther from the light bulb does not affect circuit function.

D.Choice: Replace the copper wire with a different type of metal wire.

Key.Rationale: Copper wire is an effective electrical conductor in a circuit.

SubTopics: Describe changes in motion caused by forces (e.g., magnetic, pushes or pulls, gravity, friction).
Content: Use the drawing below to answer the question.
problems/PA21G4S/media/13a.jpg
Some bicycles have brake pads that squeeze the sides of the wheels. Which statement best describes how the motion of a bicycle changes when the brakes are used?

A.Choice: The bicycle speeds up due to the friction between the brake pad and the wheel.

Key.Rationale: Frictional force reduces, not increases, the speed of the bicycle.

B.Choice: The bicycle slows down due to the friction between the brake pad and the wheel.

Key.Rationale: Frictional force between the brake pad and the wheel causes the bicycle to slow down.

C.Choice: The bicycle speeds up due to the magnetism between the brake pad and the wheel.

Key.Rationale: Frictional force is produced when brake pads squeeze the sides of the wheel.

D.Choice: The bicycle slows down due to the magnetism between the brake pad and the wheel.

Key.Rationale: Frictional force is produced when brake pads squeeze the sides of the wheel.

SubTopics: Identify various Earth structures (e.g., mountains, watersheds, peninsulas, lakes, rivers, valleys) through the use of models.
Content: Use the drawing and chart below to answer the question.
problems/PA21G4S/media/14a.jpg
problems/PA21G4S/media/14b.jpg
Which student correctly labeled the environmental features?

Key.Rationale: This student incorrectly labeled all the environmental features.
This student correctly labeled feature X (mountain), feature Y (river), and feature Z (lake) in this environment.
This student correctly labeled only feature Z (lake) in this environment.
This student correctly labeled only feature X (mountain) and feature Y (river) in this environment.

SubTopics: Describe or compare lentic systems (i.e., ponds, lakes, and bays) and lotic systems (i.e., streams, creeks, and rivers).
Content: Which statement best describes a pond?

A.Choice: It is made of salt water that is frozen.

Key.Rationale: A pond is made of fresh water.

B.Choice: It is made of salt water that is flowing.

Key.Rationale: A pond is a standing body of fresh water.

C.Choice: It is made of fresh water that does not flow.

Key.Rationale: A pond is a standing body of fresh water.

D.Choice: It is made of fresh water that does not freeze.

Key.Rationale: A pond is made of fresh water, but it can freeze in low temperatures.

SubTopics: Identify basic cloud types (i.e., cirrus, cumulus, stratus, and cumulonimbus) and make connections to basic elements of weather (e.g., changes in temperature, precipitation).
Content: In late spring, a student notices very tall, puffy clouds forming quickly in the sky. The clouds seem to be getting taller and are turning dark gray. Which weather forecast can best be made from these observations?

A.Choice: Cirrus clouds are forming and fair weather is expected.

Key.Rationale: Cirrus clouds, often seen in fair weather, are long, thin, wispy, and white.

B.Choice: Cumulus clouds are forming and dry, cold weather is expected.

Key.Rationale: Cumulus clouds are puffy white or light gray and look like cotton balls.

C.Choice: Cumulonimbus clouds are forming and a thunderstorm is likely.

Key.Rationale: Cumulonimbus clouds are thunderstorm clouds — they grow tall and become dark gray before producing severe weather events.

D.Choice: Stratus clouds are forming and a late-season snowstorm is likely.

Key.Rationale: Stratus clouds are gray and form low to the ground, covering most of the sky.

SubTopics: Identify and describe examples of common technological changes past to present in the community (e.g., energy production, transportation, communications, agriculture, packaging materials) that have either positive or negative impacts on society or the environment.
Content: Use the information below to answer the question.

:box:Objects

• horse-drawn wagon

• bicycle

• automobile

• train

• airplane

• boat
A student made a list of some objects.
Describe one similarity shared by all the objects in the list.
Choose one of the objects from the list and describe a positive or a negative impact it has had on society or the environment.

SubTopics: Describe changes in motion caused by forces (e.g., magnetic, pushes or pulls, gravity, friction).
Content: Use the drawings below to answer the question.
problems/PA21G4S/media/18a.jpg
A student pushes a bar magnet across a tabletop toward magnet X. The student repeats this action toward magnet Y.
Predict the motion of magnet X.
Predict the motion of magnet Y.
